body.p: I cannot undertake to make any explanation to Forster, or to convey anything to him that you have not yourself written. The course to take in reference to seeking a pensionCattermole, the co-illustrator of The Old Curiosity Shop and Barnaby Rudge, had died, 24 July, “Very, very poor. Family quite unprovided for; debt and distress” (To Wills, 26 July 68, Pilgrim Letters 12, pp. 158-9), and CD was assisting his family. is to memorialize Mr. D’Israeli, the Prime Minister. Disraeli had been Prime Minister since Feb. The Memorial was presented to Disraeli shortly before his resignation (Dec 68); it was presented again, to Gladstone, early in 1869 (To W. P. Frith, [19] Jan 69; Pilgrim Letters 12, p. 277): nothing came of it. It is the only course I know of. The Memorial need set forth no more than is in the “Appeal”.While doubting the usefulness of an appeal, even before Cattermole’s death (To Mrs Cattermole, 2 July 68 in Pilgrim Letters 12, pp. 144-5), CD drafted an Appeal (see Appx E) and opened an account at Coutts, which he controlled (To W. P. Frith, 16 Nov 68, Pilgrim Letters 12, p. 221). CD sent Mrs Cattermole a cheque for just over £542 in Apr 69, the entire sum collected (Pilgrim Letters 12, pp. 332-3 & nn). It should be signed by the best known Painters, and, so signed, I think would attract attention. I doubt Quin’sDr F. H. F. Quin (1799-1878; Dictionary of National Biography), homoeopathic physician. Presumably Mrs Cattermole had suggested his medical testimony would reinforce her case being of any use in the matter, and it came to my knowledge but yesterday that LyttonEdward George Bulwer-Lytton, Bart, later 1st Baron Lytton (1803-73; Dictionary of National Biography), writer and politician. is not on such terms with the Government that he will ask any favors of them. He had, in another case, Not traced. just refused to do so.
